docs.lead_paragraph: New Jersey lawmakers saved their most delicate vote for the last day of the legislative term, approving a sizable pay raise for themselves and other government officials today before officially ending the 208th legislative session. The raise, which Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is expected to sign, stirred up surprisingly little protest among New Jersey voters, who are notoriously cantankerous about taxes and sensitive to issues involving elected officials' perquisites.

headline.main: Pay Raise Passes in Trenton On Session's Busy Last Day

docs.abstract: New Jersey lawmakers save their most delicate vote for last day of legislative term, approving sizable pay raise for themselves and other government officials before officially ending 208th legislative session (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pushed by rising costs for prescription drugs and insurance premiums, growth in the nation's health care bill accelerated in 1998. Private health care spending increased by 6.9 percent, as against a 4.8 percent rise in 1997. Growth in government spending, on programs like Medicare, for the elderly and disabled, slowed to 4.1 percent, according to an annual report by the Health Care Financing Administration.

headline.main: U.S. Health Care Costs Rose Faster in 1998

docs.abstract: Growth in nation's health-care bill accelerates in 1998, pushed by rising costs for prescription drugs and insurance premiums; private health care spending increases by 6.9 percent, compared with 4.8 percent rise in 1997; growth in government spending, on programs like Medicare, for elderly and disabled, slows to 4.1 percent; overall, health care spending rises to $4,094 per person in 1998, or total of $1.1 trillion, from $3,912 per person in 1997 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: One proposition went undisputed in a case argued before the Supreme Court today: that people whose race or sex makes them the targets of unfavorable official action can sue the government for violating their constitutional right to equal protection. But what about someone who is singled out not because of membership in a particular group, but simply because a government official bears a personal grudge? As Justice Sandra Day O'Connor put the question: ''Is there a lawsuit just because the mayor in his heart of hearts hated the plaintiff?''

headline.main: Supreme Court Roundup; Justices Consider Remedy For Government Grudges

docs.abstract: Supreme Court hears arguments in suit against Willowbrook, Ill, as to whether person who is target of official ill will, unrelated to race or sex, can bring equal protection suit against government as 'class of one;' justices express concerns about involving federal courts in thousands of such cases; Supreme Court rejects Pennsylvania appeal of State Supreme Court ruling rejecting procedure for determining whether convicted sex offender is 'sexually violent predator' under state's version of law providing for continued surveillance and community notification of whereabouts of sex offenders; Supreme Court refuses to hear appeal challenging Mutual of Omaha's cap on lifetime benefits for treatment of medical needs related to HIV or AIDS (M)
docs.snippet: One proposition went undisputed in a case argued before the Supreme Court today: that people whose race or sex makes them the targets of unfavorable official action can sue the government for violating their constitutional right to equal protection. ...

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna Inc. said today that it would combine its global operations into two main units serving its health and financial businesses as it tries to raise its lagging share price. Thomas J. McInerney, president of Aetna Financial Services, will lead the financial services business, while Michael J. Cardillo, president of Aetna U.S. Healthcare, will oversee the health care unit. This places both men in the running to replace Richard Huber as chairman and chief executive, analysts said.

headline.main: Aetna Moves to Streamline Its Operations Worldwide

docs.abstract: Aetna Inc will combine its global operations into two main units serving its health and financial businesses as it tries to raise its lagging share price; Thomas J McInerney, president of Aetna Financial Services, will lead financial services businesses, while Michael J Cardillo, president of Aetna US Healthcare, will oversee health care unit (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Enrollment in a new health insurance program for children doubled last year, to nearly two million, and President Clinton will propose a $2.7 billion initiative to sign up more children, White House officials said today. Enrollment is still far short of the five million children Mr. Clinton set as a goal when he signed the legislation creating the program in August 1997. But the program got off to a slow start, and the Census Bureau says the number of children without health insurance has increased since Mr. Clinton signed the bill.

headline.main: Clinton to Broaden Effort in Children's Health Coverage

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration reports enrollment in new health insurance program for children whose families earn too much for Medicaid, but are too poor to afford private health insurance, doubled last year, to nearly two million; says Clinton will propose $2.7 billion initiative to sign up more children; Census Bureau says number of uninsured children rose since Clinton signed bill for program in Aug 1997 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-10 Israel-Syria Peace Talks To Resume After Break The United States said it would reconvene the negotiations on Jan. 19 to avoid losing the momentum built up in the eight days of talks that ended yesterday. The decision by the United States, which is acting as mediator, reflected an upbeat sense that some progress had been made. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: Late one evening, about a year ago, Juston Paul, 10, saw the light on in the bathroom. Peeking in, he saw his mother changing the bandage on a large incision on her left breast. Juston had known for some time that his mother, Tammy Paul, now 38, had breast cancer.

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Mother's Illness Took a Toll on Her Son

docs.lead_paragraph: Almost any time Graham Pewter is in the air -- and that is pretty often -- you are likely to see him wearing headphones and a smile. Mr. Pewter, chief executive of Commercial Risk Partners, a Bermuda subsidiary of SCOR, the big French insurer, may be skimming through financial documents with a highlighter pen in hand. But he is also listening to the blues. ''I started playing drums in high school in London,'' Mr. Pewter said. ''Then I got my hair cut and interviewed with banks and insurance companies.'' He signed with an insurer, he said, because ''they paid better.''
docs.abstract: Graham Pewter, Commercial Risk Partners chief executive, comments on contents of his briefcase; photos (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Since opening in 1922, Deborah Heart and Lung Center in Browns Mills has never billed a patient, and to this day it relies on private insurance, government health plans and subsidies and fund-raising to pay its bills. But the 161-bed hospital's policy of waiving copayments for Medicare outpatients is under scrutiny by the federal agency that administers Medicare, The Wall Street Journal reported last week.

headline.main: Government Considers Forcing Hospital to Charge Patients

docs.abstract: Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which administers Medicare, is scrutinizing Deborah Heart and Lung Center in Browns Mill, NJ, which, since its 1922 opening, has never charged patients for treatment (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Marriage rates in New York City are at their lowest levels since the era when the Bee Gees ruled the airwaves, Farrah Fawcett sold her own shampoo and the first test-tube baby was born in England. Economic incentives that make the single life attractive, a dearth of twentysomethings and an increased social acceptance of lives lived under one roof without a certificate are among the chief reasons for the decline, sociologists say.

headline.main: In State of Wedlock, Declining Number of Arrivals From New York

docs.abstract: Marriage rates in New York City are at lowest levels since late 1970's; economic incentives that make single life attractive, a dearth of twentysomethings and an increased social acceptance of cohabitation are among the chief reasons for decline cited by sociologists; graph (M)
